sen.j: 宝積寺（ほうしゃくじ）は京都府乙訓郡大山崎町の天王山中腹にある真言宗智山派の仏教寺院。
sen.e: Hoshaku-ji Temple is a Buddhist temple belonging to the Chizan Branch of the Shingon Sect located on the side of Mt. Tennozan.
Hoshaku-ji Temple is a Buddhist temple belonging to the Chizan Branch of the Shingon Sect located on the side of Mt. Tennozan.
Hoshaku-ji Temple is a Buddhist temple belonging to the Chizan School of the Shingon Sect located on the side of Mt. Tenno in Oyamazaki-cho, Otokuni-gun, Kyoto Prefecture.
sen.cmt: ～派用語統一山表記統一住所表記

sen.j: 山号は天王山または銭原山（古くは補陀洛山といった）、本尊は十一面観音である。
sen.e: Its honorific mountain prefix is 'Tennozan' or 'Sengensan' (formerly Fudarakuzan) and the principal image is a statue of the Eleven-faced Kannon.
Its honorific mountain prefix is 'Tennozan' or 'Sengensan' (formerly Fudarakuzan) and the principal image is a statue of the Eleven-faced Kannon.

Its sango (literally, "mountain name"), which is the title prefixed to the name of a Buddhist temple, is 'Tennozan' or 'Sengensan' (formerly Fudarakuzan) and the principal image is a statue of the Eleven-faced Kannon.
sen.cmt: honorific mountain prefix→sango (literally, "mountain name"), which is the title prefixed to the name of a Buddhist temple

sen.j: 724年、聖武天皇の勅命を受けた行基による開基と伝える。
sen.e: The temple was founded by Gyoki in the year 724 under the order of Emperor Shomu.
The temple was founded by Gyoki in the year 724 under the order of Emperor Shomu.
The temple was founded by Gyoki in the year 724 under the order of Emperor Shomu.

sen.j: 聖武天皇が夢で竜神から授けられたという「打出」と「小槌」（打出と小槌は別のもの）を祀ることから「宝寺」（たからでら）の別名があり、大黒天宝寺ともいう。
sen.e: It is also known as "Takara-dera Temple" and "Daikoku Tenpo-ji Temple" as it also houses the "uchide" and "kozuchi" magic hammers that Emperor Shomu is said to have received from the dragon god in a dream.

It is also known as "Takara-dera Temple" and "Daikoku Tenpo-ji Temple" as it also houses the "uchide" and "kozuchi" magic hammers that Emperor Shomu is said to have received from the dragon god in a dream.

sen.j: 歴史
sen.e: History
History
History

sen.j: 宝積寺は、山城国（京都府）と摂津国（大阪府）の境に位置し、古くから交通・軍事上の要地であった天王山（270m）の南側山腹にあり、寺伝では神亀元年（724年）、聖武天皇の勅願により行基が建立したと伝える。
sen.e: According to temple legend, Hoshaku-ji Temple was founded by Gyoki on the order of Emperor Shomu in the year 724 on the southern face of Mt. Tennozan (270m), which is located on the boarder between what was once Yamashiro Province (Kyoto Prefecture) and Settsu Province (Osaka Prefecture), and has been a key transportation and military location since ancient times.

According to temple legend, Hoshaku-ji Temple was founded by Gyoki on the order of Emperor Shomu in the year 724 on the southern face of Mt. Tennozan (270m), which is located on the boarder between what was once Yamashiro Province (Kyoto Prefecture) and Settsu Province (Osaka Prefecture), and has been a key transportation and military location since ancient times.

According to temple legend, Hoshaku-ji Temple was founded by Gyoki on the order of Emperor Shomu in the year 724 on the southern face of Mt. Tenno (270 m), which is located on the boarder between what was once Yamashiro Province (Kyoto Prefecture) and Settsu Province (Osaka Prefecture), and has been a key transportation and military location since ancient times.
sen.cmt: 山用語統一スペース挿入

sen.j: 行基は奈良時代に架橋、灌漑などの社会事業を行い、多くの寺を建てた僧である。
sen.e: Gyoki was a monk who engaged in social work such as the construction of bridges and the introduction of irrigation during the Nara period.
Gyoki was a monk who engaged in social work such as the construction of bridges and the introduction of irrigation during the Nara period.
Gyoki was a monk who engaged in social work such as the construction of bridges and the introduction of irrigation during the Nara period and he also built many temples.
sen.cmt: and he also built many temples補足

sen.j: 行基は神亀2年（725年）、淀川に「山崎橋」（山崎－橋本間）を架けている。
sen.e: In the year 725, he worked on the "Yamazaki-bashi Bridge" (between Yamazaki and Hashimoto) over the Yodo-gawa River.
In the year 725, he worked on the "Yamazaki-bashi Bridge" (between Yamazaki and Hashimoto) over the Yodo-gawa River.
In the year 725, he worked on the 'Yamazaki-bashi Bridge' (between Yamazaki and Hashimoto) over the Yodo-gawa River.

sen.j: また、『行基年譜』によれば、行基は天平3年（731年）、乙訓郡山崎に「山崎院」を建立している。
sen.e: According to "Gyoki Nenpu", he also established Yamazaki-in Temple in Yamazaki, Otokuni County.
According to "Gyoki Nenpu", he also established Yamazaki-in Temple in Yamazaki, Otokuni County.
According to "Gyoki Nenpu," he also established Yamazaki-in Temple in Yamazaki, Otokuni County in 731.
sen.cmt: カンマの位置移動年号補足

sen.j: 天王山の南側山麓に位置する大山崎町大山崎上ノ田の遺跡が「山崎院」跡に比定されており、ここからは日本でも最古級の壁画断片などが出土している。
sen.e: The ruins at Oyamazaki Uenoda, Oyamazaki-cho on the southern base of Mt. Tennozan are believed to be those of "Yamazaki-in Temple" and are where fragments of Japan's oldest wall painting were unearthed.

The ruins at Oyamazaki Uenoda, Oyamazaki-cho on the southern base of Mt. Tennozan are believed to be those of "Yamazaki-in Temple" and are where fragments of Japan's oldest wall painting were unearthed.
The ruins at Oyamazaki Uenoda, Oyamazaki-cho on the southern base of Mt. Tenno are believed to be those of 'Yamazaki-in Temple' and are where fragments of Japan's oldest wall painting were unearthed.

sen.j: 以上のことから、天王山周辺は行基にゆかりの深い地であることは確かで、宝積寺は「山崎院」の後身と考える説もある。
sen.e: It is certain from the above evidence that the area surrounding Mt. Tennozan holds a deep connection to Gyoki and there is a theory that Hoshaku-ji Temple is the successor to "Yamazaki-in Temple".
It is certain from the above evidence that the area surrounding Mt. Tennozan holds a deep connection to Gyoki and there is a theory that Hoshaku-ji Temple is the successor to "Yamazaki-in Temple".
It is certain from the above evidence that the area surrounding Mt. Tenno holds a deep connection to Gyoki and there is a theory that Hoshaku-ji Temple is the successor to 'Yamazaki-in Temple.'
sen.cmt: "→'山用語統一ピリオド位置移動

sen.j: 宝積寺は貞永元年（1232年）の火災で焼失しており、現存する仏像等はこれ以降のものである。
sen.e: Hoshaku-ji Temple was destroyed by fire in 1232 and the items such as Buddha statues that survive today date from after this year.
Hoshaku-ji Temple was destroyed by fire in 1232 and the items such as Buddha statues that survive today date from after this year.
Hoshaku-ji Temple was destroyed by fire in 1232 and the items such as Buddha statues that survive today date from after this year.

sen.j: それ以前の寺史はあまり明らかでないが、長徳年間（995－999年）、寂照が中興したという。
sen.e: The history of the temple after this time is unclear but it is known to have been restored by Jakusho between the year 995 and 999.
The history of the temple after this time is unclear but it is known to have been restored by Jakusho between the year 995 and 999.
The history of the temple after this time is unclear but it is known to have been restored by Jakusho between the year 995 and 999.

sen.j: 寂昭は俗名を大江定基といい、『今昔物語集』所収の説話で知られる。
sen.e: Jakusho's secular name was OE no Sadamoto, and he is known from a tale included in "Konjaku Monogatarishu" (lit. Anthology of Tales from the Past).
Jakusho's secular name was OE no Sadamoto, and he is known from a tale included in "Konjaku Monogatarishu" (lit. Anthology of Tales from the Past).

sen.cmt: 今昔物語集の英語説明統一

sen.j: それによれば、彼は三河守として任国に赴任していた時に最愛の女性を亡くし、世をはかなんで出家したという。
sen.e: This story tells that he left his old life behind and entered the priesthood after the love of his life died when he was appointed governor of Mikawa Province.
This story tells that he left his old life behind and entered the priesthood after the love of his life died when he was appointed governor of Mikawa Province.
This story tells that he left his old life behind and entered the priesthood after the love of his life died when he was appointed governor of Mikawa Province.

sen.j: 11世紀末から12世紀初めの成立と思われる『続本朝往生伝』（大江匡房著）には早くも当寺の通称である「宝寺」の名が見える。
sen.e: The work entitled "Zoku Honcho-ojo-den" (written by OE no Masafusa) believed to have been written from the late 11th century to the early 12th century contains early references to the temple as "Ho-ji Temple".

The work entitled "Zoku Honcho-ojo-den" (written by OE no Masafusa) believed to have been written from the late 11th century to the early 12th century contains early references to the temple as "Ho-ji Temple".

The work entitled "Zoku Honcho-ojo-den" (Sequel to the Accounts of Rebirth into the Pure Land) (written by OE no Masafusa) believed to have been written from the late 11th century to the early 12th century contains early references to the temple as 'Ho-ji Temple.'
sen.cmt: "→'(Sequel to the Accounts of Rebirth into the Pure Land)補足

sen.j: また、藤原定家の日記「明月記」には建仁2年（1202年）に彼が宝積寺を訪れたことが記されている。
sen.e: FUJIWARA no Sadaie recorded in his diary, "Meigetsuki", that he visited Hoshaku-ji Temple in 1202.
FUJIWARA no Sadaie recorded in his diary, "Meigetsuki", that he visited Hoshaku-ji Temple in 1202.
FUJIWARA no Sadaie recorded in his diary, 'Meigetsuki,' that he visited Hoshaku-ji Temple in 1202.

sen.j: 天正10年（1582年）、天王山が豊臣秀吉と明智光秀が戦った山崎の合戦の舞台となり、その際宝積寺には秀吉の本陣が置かれた。
sen.e: When Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI and Mitsuhide AKECHI fought at the Battle of Yamazaki on Mt. Tennozan in 1582, Hoshaku-ji Temple served as Hideyoshi's headquarters.
When Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI and Mitsuhide AKECHI fought at the Battle of Yamazaki on Mt. Tennozan in 1582, Hoshaku-ji Temple served as Hideyoshi's headquarters.
When Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI and Mitsuhide AKECHI fought at the Battle of Yamazaki on Mt. Tenno in 1582, Hoshaku-ji Temple served as Hideyoshi's headquarters.

sen.j: 直後秀吉により天王山に建設された「山崎城」にも取り込まれ、このため城は「宝寺城」とも呼ばれた。
sen.e: When Yamazaki Castle was constructed on Mt. Tennozan directly after the conflict, it enveloped the temple and for this reason became known as "Hoji Castle".
When Yamazaki Castle was constructed on Mt. Tennozan directly after the conflict, it enveloped the temple and for this reason became known as "Hoji Castle".
When Yamazaki-jo Castle was constructed on Mt. Tenno directly after the conflict, it enveloped the temple and for this reason became known as 'Hoji-jo Castle'.
sen.cmt: 城用語統一山用語統一"→'

sen.j: 元治元年（1864年）には禁門の変で尊皇攘夷派の真木和泉守を始めとする十七烈士らの陣地がおかれた。
sen.e: During the Hamaguri Rebellion in 1864, the temple served as a base for the seventeen patriots including Maki Izuminokami of the Sonno joi (lit. Revere the Emperor, Expel the Barbarians) faction.
During the Hamaguri Rebellion in 1864, the temple served as a base for the seventeen patriots including Maki Izuminokami of the Sonno joi (lit. Revere the Emperor, Expel the Barbarians) faction.

sen.j: 明治時代には夏目漱石が「漱石日記」に宝積寺について記している。
sen.e: In the Meiji era, Soseki NATSUME wrote of Hoshaku-ji Temple in his diary "Soseki Nikki".

sen.j: 閻魔堂安置の閻魔王、司命、司録、倶生神、闇黒童子の各像は、天王山西麓の大阪府島本町にあった西観音寺旧蔵で、同寺が明治の廃仏毀釈で廃寺になったため宝積寺に移された。
sen.e: The Enma-o, Shimyo, Shiroku, Kushijin and Ankoku Doji statues were formerly owned by Nishi-Kannon-ji Temple on the western base of Mt. Tennozan in Shimamoto-cho, Osaka Prefecture but were transferred to Hoshaku-ji Temple after this temple closed during the anti-Buddhist movement at the beginning of the Meiji era.

The Enma-o, Shimyo, Shiroku, Kushijin and Ankoku Doji statues were formerly owned by Nishi-Kannon-ji Temple on the western base of Mt. Tennozan in Shimamoto-cho, Osaka Prefecture but were transferred to Hoshaku-ji Temple after this temple closed during the anti-Buddhist movement at the beginning of the Meiji era.

The Enma-o, Shimyo, Shiroku, Kushijin and Ankoku Doji statues, which are enshrined in Enma-do, were formerly owned by Nishi-Kannon-ji Temple on the western base of Mt. Tenno in Shimamoto-cho, Osaka Prefecture but were transferred to Hoshaku-ji Temple after this temple closed during the anti-Buddhist movement at the beginning of the Meiji period.

sen.j: いずれも鎌倉時代の作で、閻魔一族の像としては日本でも古くかつ優れた作品の1つである。
sen.e: These statues were all created during the Kamakura period and are the oldest and some of the best quality statues of the Enma family in Japan.

sen.j: なお、閻魔王以外の各像の名称には混乱があるようで、巻物をもつ倶生神像と筆をもつ闇黒童子像の一対が本来の「司命・司録」像であることが指摘されている。
sen.e: There is some confusion regarding the names of the statues other than that of Enma-o, with the statue of Kushijin holding a scroll and the statue of Ankoku Doji holding a writing brush originally being identified as "Shimyo and Shiroku".
